Description: Scarab carved from steatite; back rather well detailed with deeply cut grooves delineating the main features of clypeus, prothorax and elytra divisions; V-incisions on elytra at junction with prothorax on each side; at side, rather well-shaped legs with undercut triangular space between front and back legs; underside bearing deeply incised motif arranged vertically with crude hieroglyphic signs, including ointment jar Bastet, ntr sign and ichneumon; pierced lengthways; steatite now mostly off white; slightly chipped.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The presence of such an early type of scarab in Naukratis can be interpreted in many ways: heirloom, brought from a nearby site in antiquity or by sebakhin, archaizing copy of the 25th or 26th dynasty… (on the various early scarabs from Naukratis see: Masson forthcoming). Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Egyptian Naukratis: the early evidence’, in A. Wodzińska (ed.), Delta and Sinai Current research, Proceedings of the conference in the University of Warsaw, Warsaw, April 25-27 2013.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 174)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.26) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol
